question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What's the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why's Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What's Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where's the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where's the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What's Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What's the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What's a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What's special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why's it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What's Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why's Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What's the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why's Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What's Venus?
answer: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the hottest planet in our Solar System.

question: Is Venus bigger or smaller than Earth?
answer: Venus is almost the same size as Earth – it’s like Earth’s twin sister!

question: Why do we call Venus Earth’s twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size and made of rock, but it’s way too hot to live on.

question: How far is Venus from the Sun?
answer: Venus is about 108 million kilometers (67 million miles) from the Sun.

question: How hot is Venus?
answer: It’s over 460°C (860°F) all the time – hot enough to melt lead!

question: Why's Venus the hottest planet?
answer: It has a super thick blanket of carbon dioxide gas that traps heat like a giant greenhouse.

question: What's the greenhouse effect on Venus?
answer: The thick atmosphere traps the Sun’s heat so it can’t escape, making the planet super toasty.

question: Does Venus have any moons?
answer: No, Venus has zero moons.

question: How long is one day on Venus?
answer: One day on Venus (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 243 Earth days – longer than its year!

question: How long is a year on Venus?
answer: A year on Venus is 225 Earth days – shorter than on Earth.

question: Why does Venus spin backwards?
answer: Venus spins the opposite way from most planets – on Venus the Sun rises in the west!

question: What color is Venus in the sky?
answer: Venus is bright white-yellow and is the brightest thing in the sky after the Sun and Moon.

question: Why's Venus so bright from Earth?
answer: It’s covered in thick white clouds that reflect sunlight really well, and it comes quite close to Earth.

question: Can we see Venus without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s often called the Evening Star or Morning Star because it shines so brightly.

question: What are the clouds on Venus made of?
answer: They’re made of sulfuric acid – like nasty, poisonous rain that never reaches the ground.

question: Does it rain on Venus?
answer: Yes, but the rain is sulfuric acid and it evaporates before hitting the ground.

question: What's the surface of Venus like?
answer: It’s rocky with thousands of volcanoes, huge lava plains, and mountains.

question: Are there active volcanoes on Venus?
answer: Scientists think some might still be active – Venus is a very volcanic world!

question: How thick is Venus’s atmosphere?
answer: It’s about 90 times thicker than Earth’s – it would crush you like the bottom of the ocean.

question: Can humans breathe on Venus?
answer: No way! The air is mostly carbon dioxide and full of poisonous gases.

question: Who was Venus named after?
answer: Venus was named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty because it looks so pretty in the sky.

question: How many spacecraft have landed on Venus?
answer: Only Soviet spacecraft have landed – the Venera probes – and they melted quickly!

question: How long did the longest Venus lander survive?
answer: The record is about 2 hours before the heat and pressure destroyed it.

question: Is there lightning on Venus?
answer: Yes! Scientists have seen huge lightning storms in the thick clouds.

question: Why does Venus have almost no water?
answer: The extreme heat long ago boiled all the water away into space.

question: Does Venus have craters?
answer: Not many – lava from volcanoes covered most old craters.

question: What's the highest mountain on Venus?
answer: Maxwell Montes – it’s taller than Mount Everest!

question: How strong is the wind on Venus?
answer: Near the ground it’s slow, but high in the clouds it blows over 350 km/h – faster than a hurricane!

question: What's super-rotation on Venus?
answer: The clouds go all the way around the planet in just 4 Earth days even though the planet spins slowly.

question: Is there ice on Venus?
answer: No – it’s far too hot everywhere for ice.

question: What's Venus’s sky color if you stood there?
answer: It would look orange-yellow because of the thick clouds.

question: Can people ever live on Venus?
answer: Not on the ground, but some scientists dream about floating cities high in the cooler clouds.

question: How much would you weigh on Venus?
answer: Almost the same as on Earth because it’s nearly the same size and gravity.

question: What's a transit of Venus?
answer: When Venus passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a small black dot on the Sun.

question: How often does a transit of Venus happen?
answer: Very rarely – they come in pairs 8 years apart, then wait over 100 years.

question: Does Venus have seasons?
answer: No, because it has almost no tilt – every day is the same.

question: Where's the pressure highest on Venus?
answer: On the surface – it’s like being 900 meters under the ocean on Earth.

question: Why can’t we see the surface of Venus with normal telescopes?
answer: The thick clouds hide everything – we need radar to see through them.

question: What spacecraft mapped Venus with radar?
answer: The Magellan spacecraft in the 1990s made the best maps of the hidden surface.

question: Is Venus getting hotter or cooler?
answer: It’s stayed about the same super-hot temperature for billions of years.

question: What's the Soviet Venera program?
answer: A series of brave Russian probes that took the only photos ever from Venus’s surface.

question: Can you see stars from Venus during the day?
answer: No – the thick clouds make the sky bright all the time.

question: Why does Venus shine so long in the evening?
answer: It follows the Sun down or comes up before the Sun, so we can see it for hours.

question: Does Venus have earthquakes?
answer: They’re called venusquakes – the ground sometimes shakes from shrinking or volcanoes.

question: How many volcanoes are on Venus?
answer: Over 1,600 big ones have been counted, and probably millions of small ones!

question: Is Venus a rocky planet?
answer: Yes, it’s a rocky terrestrial planet just like Earth, Mercury, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you took off your spacesuit on Venus?
answer: You’d be crushed, burned, and poisoned all at once in seconds!

question: Will we go back to Venus soon?
answer: Yes! NASA and Europe are planning new missions like VERITAS and EnVision for the 2030s.

question: What's special about Venus’s day being longer than its year?
answer: It’s the only planet where a day lasts longer than a year – very strange!

question: Why's Venus sometimes called Earth’s evil twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size but turned into a deadly hot hell instead of a nice home.

question: What's Venus?
answer: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the hottest planet in our Solar System.

question: Is Venus bigger or smaller than Earth?
answer: Venus is almost the same size as Earth – it’s like Earth’s twin sister!

question: Why do we call Venus Earth’s twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size and made of rock, but it’s way too hot to live on.

question: How far is Venus from the Sun?
answer: Venus is about 108 million kilometers (67 million miles) from the Sun.

question: How hot is Venus?
answer: It’s over 460°C (860°F) all the time – hot enough to melt lead!

question: Why's Venus the hottest planet?
answer: It has a super thick blanket of carbon dioxide gas that traps heat like a giant greenhouse.

question: What's the greenhouse effect on Venus?
answer: The thick atmosphere traps the Sun’s heat so it can’t escape, making the planet super toasty.

question: Does Venus have any moons?
answer: No, Venus has zero moons.

question: How long is one day on Venus?
answer: One day on Venus (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 243 Earth days – longer than its year!

question: How long is a year on Venus?
answer: A year on Venus is 225 Earth days – shorter than on Earth.

question: Why does Venus spin backwards?
answer: Venus spins the opposite way from most planets – on Venus the Sun rises in the west!

question: What color is Venus in the sky?
answer: Venus is bright white-yellow and is the brightest thing in the sky after the Sun and Moon.

question: Why's Venus so bright from Earth?
answer: It’s covered in thick white clouds that reflect sunlight really well, and it comes quite close to Earth.

question: Can we see Venus without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s often called the Evening Star or Morning Star because it shines so brightly.

question: What are the clouds on Venus made of?
answer: They’re made of sulfuric acid – like nasty, poisonous rain that never reaches the ground.

question: Does it rain on Venus?
answer: Yes, but the rain is sulfuric acid and it evaporates before hitting the ground.

question: What's the surface of Venus like?
answer: It’s rocky with thousands of volcanoes, huge lava plains, and mountains.

question: Are there active volcanoes on Venus?
answer: Scientists think some might still be active – Venus is a very volcanic world!

question: How thick is Venus’s atmosphere?
answer: It’s about 90 times thicker than Earth’s – it would crush you like the bottom of the ocean.

question: Can humans breathe on Venus?
answer: No way! The air is mostly carbon dioxide and full of poisonous gases.

question: Who was Venus named after?
answer: Venus was named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty because it looks so pretty in the sky.

question: How many spacecraft have landed on Venus?
answer: Only Soviet spacecraft have landed – the Venera probes – and they melted quickly!

question: How long did the longest Venus lander survive?
answer: The record is about 2 hours before the heat and pressure destroyed it.

question: Is there lightning on Venus?
answer: Yes! Scientists have seen huge lightning storms in the thick clouds.

question: Why does Venus have almost no water?
answer: The extreme heat long ago boiled all the water away into space.

question: Does Venus have craters?
answer: Not many – lava from volcanoes covered most old craters.

question: What's the highest mountain on Venus?
answer: Maxwell Montes – it’s taller than Mount Everest!

question: How strong is the wind on Venus?
answer: Near the ground it’s slow, but high in the clouds it blows over 350 km/h – faster than a hurricane!

question: What's super-rotation on Venus?
answer: The clouds go all the way around the planet in just 4 Earth days even though the planet spins slowly.

question: Is there ice on Venus?
answer: No – it’s far too hot everywhere for ice.

question: What's Venus’s sky color if you stood there?
answer: It would look orange-yellow because of the thick clouds.

question: Can people ever live on Venus?
answer: Not on the ground, but some scientists dream about floating cities high in the cooler clouds.

question: How much would you weigh on Venus?
answer: Almost the same as on Earth because it’s nearly the same size and gravity.

question: What's a transit of Venus?
answer: When Venus passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a small black dot on the Sun.

question: How often does a transit of Venus happen?
answer: Very rarely – they come in pairs 8 years apart, then wait over 100 years.

question: Does Venus have seasons?
answer: No, because it has almost no tilt – every day is the same.

question: Where's the pressure highest on Venus?
answer: On the surface – it’s like being 900 meters under the ocean on Earth.

question: Why can’t we see the surface of Venus with normal telescopes?
answer: The thick clouds hide everything – we need radar to see through them.

question: What spacecraft mapped Venus with radar?
answer: The Magellan spacecraft in the 1990s made the best maps of the hidden surface.

question: Is Venus getting hotter or cooler?
answer: It’s stayed about the same super-hot temperature for billions of years.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: Mercury has extreme temperature variations, with daytime temperatures reaching up to 430°C (800°F) on the side facing the sun, while night time temperatures can plummet to -180°C (-290°F) on the side facing away.

question: What is mercury's temperature?
answer: Daytime temperatures on Mercury soar to about 430 degrees Celsius, but at night they drop dramatically to around -180 degrees Celsius due to its thin atmosphere.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: Mercury experiences the most extreme temperature swings in the solar system, from 430°C during the day to -180°C at night because it lacks substantial atmosphere.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: On the sun-facing side, Mercury heats up to 430°C, while the dark side cools to -180°C, creating one of the largest temperature ranges of any planet.

question: What's Mercury's temperature?
answer: The temperature on Mercury varies wildly from 430°C in sunlight to -180°C in shadow, all because it has almost no atmosphere to retain heat.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: Mercury's surface can be scorching hot at 430°C during its long day and freezing cold at -180°C during its long night due to minimal atmospheric insulation.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: You'll find extreme heat (430°C) and extreme cold (-180°C) on different sides of Mercury simultaneously because its thin atmosphere can't distribute heat effectively.

question: What's Mercury's temperature?
answer: Temperatures on Mercury range from a blistering 430°C to a frigid -180°C, making it a planet of dramatic contrasts in thermal conditions.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: Mercury bakes at 430°C when facing the sun and freezes at -180°C when turned away, thanks to its inability to hold onto atmospheric heat.

question: What is Mercury's temperature?
answer: The thermometer on Mercury would swing from 430°C to -180°C, representing some of the most extreme temperature variations in our solar system.

question: What is Venus's temperature?
answer: Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system with surface temperatures around 465°C (870°F), hot enough to melt lead, due to its thick, carbon dioxide-rich atmosphere creating a runaway greenhouse effect.

question: What is venus's temperature?
answer: With an average surface temperature of about 465°C, Venus is even hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun, thanks to its intense greenhouse atmosphere.

question: What is Venus's temperature?
answer: Venus experiences constant surface temperatures around 465°C day and night, year-round, because its thick atmosphere traps heat incredibly efficiently.

question: What is Venus's temperature?
answer: The temperature on Venus is consistently around 465°C everywhere on the planet, maintained by a dense atmosphere of carbon dioxide that creates extreme greenhouse heating.

question: What is Venus's temperature?
answer: Venus's surface is incredibly hot at approximately 465°C, a result of the thick clouds and carbon dioxide atmosphere that trap solar energy like a blanket.

question: What is Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why is Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What is the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why is Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What is the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why is Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What is Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where is the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where is the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What is Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What is the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What is a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What is special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why is it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What is Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why is Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What is the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why is Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What is the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why is Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What is Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where is the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where is the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What is Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What is the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What is a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What is special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why is it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What is Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where is the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where is the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What is Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What is the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What is a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What is special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why is it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What is Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why is Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What is the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why is Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What is the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why is Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What is the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why is Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What is the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why is Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What is Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where is the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where is the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What is Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What is the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What is a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What is special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why is it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What is Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why is Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What is Venus?
answer: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the hottest planet in our Solar System.

question: Is Venus bigger or smaller than Earth?
answer: Venus is almost the same size as Earth – it’s like Earth’s twin sister!

question: Why do we call Venus Earth’s twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size and made of rock, but it’s way too hot to live on.

question: How far is Venus from the Sun?
answer: Venus is about 108 million kilometers (67 million miles) from the Sun.

question: How hot is Venus?
answer: It’s over 460°C (860°F) all the time – hot enough to melt lead!

question: Why is Venus the hottest planet?
answer: It has a super thick blanket of carbon dioxide gas that traps heat like a giant greenhouse.

question: What is the greenhouse effect on Venus?
answer: The thick atmosphere traps the Sun’s heat so it can’t escape, making the planet super toasty.

question: Does Venus have any moons?
answer: No, Venus has zero moons.

question: How long is one day on Venus?
answer: One day on Venus (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 243 Earth days – longer than its year!

question: How long is a year on Venus?
answer: A year on Venus is 225 Earth days – shorter than on Earth.

question: Why does Venus spin backwards?
answer: Venus spins the opposite way from most planets – on Venus the Sun rises in the west!

question: What color is Venus in the sky?
answer: Venus is bright white-yellow and is the brightest thing in the sky after the Sun and Moon.

question: Why is Venus so bright from Earth?
answer: It’s covered in thick white clouds that reflect sunlight really well, and it comes quite close to Earth.

question: Can we see Venus without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s often called the Evening Star or Morning Star because it shines so brightly.

question: What are the clouds on Venus made of?
answer: They’re made of sulfuric acid – like nasty, poisonous rain that never reaches the ground.

question: Does it rain on Venus?
answer: Yes, but the rain is sulfuric acid and it evaporates before hitting the ground.

question: What is the surface of Venus like?
answer: It’s rocky with thousands of volcanoes, huge lava plains, and mountains.

question: Are there active volcanoes on Venus?
answer: Scientists think some might still be active – Venus is a very volcanic world!

question: How thick is Venus’s atmosphere?
answer: It’s about 90 times thicker than Earth’s – it would crush you like the bottom of the ocean.

question: Can humans breathe on Venus?
answer: No way! The air is mostly carbon dioxide and full of poisonous gases.

question: Who was Venus named after?
answer: Venus was named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty because it looks so pretty in the sky.

question: How many spacecraft have landed on Venus?
answer: Only Soviet spacecraft have landed – the Venera probes – and they melted quickly!

question: How long did the longest Venus lander survive?
answer: The record is about 2 hours before the heat and pressure destroyed it.

question: Is there lightning on Venus?
answer: Yes! Scientists have seen huge lightning storms in the thick clouds.

question: Why does Venus have almost no water?
answer: The extreme heat long ago boiled all the water away into space.

question: Does Venus have craters?
answer: Not many – lava from volcanoes covered most old craters.

question: What is the highest mountain on Venus?
answer: Maxwell Montes – it’s taller than Mount Everest!

question: How strong is the wind on Venus?
answer: Near the ground it’s slow, but high in the clouds it blows over 350 km/h – faster than a hurricane!

question: What is super-rotation on Venus?
answer: The clouds go all the way around the planet in just 4 Earth days even though the planet spins slowly.

question: Is there ice on Venus?
answer: No – it’s far too hot everywhere for ice.

question: What is Venus’s sky color if you stood there?
answer: It would look orange-yellow because of the thick clouds.

question: Can people ever live on Venus?
answer: Not on the ground, but some scientists dream about floating cities high in the cooler clouds.

question: How much would you weigh on Venus?
answer: Almost the same as on Earth because it’s nearly the same size and gravity.

question: What is a transit of Venus?
answer: When Venus passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a small black dot on the Sun.

question: How often does a transit of Venus happen?
answer: Very rarely – they come in pairs 8 years apart, then wait over 100 years.

question: Does Venus have seasons?
answer: No, because it has almost no tilt – every day is the same.

question: Where is the pressure highest on Venus?
answer: On the surface – it’s like being 900 meters under the ocean on Earth.

question: Why can’t we see the surface of Venus with normal telescopes?
answer: The thick clouds hide everything – we need radar to see through them.

question: What spacecraft mapped Venus with radar?
answer: The Magellan spacecraft in the 1990s made the best maps of the hidden surface.

question: Is Venus getting hotter or cooler?
answer: It’s stayed about the same super-hot temperature for billions of years.

question: What is the Soviet Venera program?
answer: A series of brave Russian probes that took the only photos ever from Venus’s surface.

question: Can you see stars from Venus during the day?
answer: No – the thick clouds make the sky bright all the time.

question: Why does Venus shine so long in the evening?
answer: It follows the Sun down or comes up before the Sun, so we can see it for hours.

question: Does Venus have earthquakes?
answer: They’re called venusquakes – the ground sometimes shakes from shrinking or volcanoes.

question: How many volcanoes are on Venus?
answer: Over 1,600 big ones have been counted, and probably millions of small ones!

question: Is Venus a rocky planet?
answer: Yes, it’s a rocky terrestrial planet just like Earth, Mercury, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you took off your spacesuit on Venus?
answer: You’d be crushed, burned, and poisoned all at once in seconds!

question: Will we go back to Venus soon?
answer: Yes! NASA and Europe are planning new missions like VERITAS and EnVision for the 2030s.

question: What is special about Venus’s day being longer than its year?
answer: It’s the only planet where a day lasts longer than a year – very strange!

question: Why is Venus sometimes called Earth’s evil twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size but turned into a deadly hot hell instead of a nice home.

question: Is Venus getting hotter or cooler?
answer: It’s stayed about the same super-hot temperature for billions of years.

question: What is the Soviet Venera program?
answer: A series of brave Russian probes that took the only photos ever from Venus’s surface.

question: Can you see stars from Venus during the day?
answer: No – the thick clouds make the sky bright all the time.

question: Why does Venus shine so long in the evening?
answer: It follows the Sun down or comes up before the Sun, so we can see it for hours.

question: Does Venus have earthquakes?
answer: They’re called venusquakes – the ground sometimes shakes from shrinking or volcanoes.

question: How many volcanoes are on Venus?
answer: Over 1,600 big ones have been counted, and probably millions of small ones!

question: Is Venus a rocky planet?
answer: Yes, it’s a rocky terrestrial planet just like Earth, Mercury, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you took off your spacesuit on Venus?
answer: You’d be crushed, burned, and poisoned all at once in seconds!

question: Will we go back to Venus soon?
answer: Yes! NASA and Europe are planning new missions like VERITAS and EnVision for the 2030s.

question: What is special about Venus’s day being longer than its year?
answer: It’s the only planet where a day lasts longer than a year – very strange!

question: Why is Venus sometimes called Earth’s evil twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size but turned into a deadly hot hell instead of a nice home.

question: What is Venus?
answer: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the hottest planet in our Solar System.

question: Is Venus bigger or smaller than Earth?
answer: Venus is almost the same size as Earth – it’s like Earth’s twin sister!

question: Why do we call Venus Earth’s twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size and made of rock, but it’s way too hot to live on.

question: How far is Venus from the Sun?
answer: Venus is about 108 million kilometers (67 million miles) from the Sun.

question: How hot is Venus?
answer: It’s over 460°C (860°F) all the time – hot enough to melt lead!

question: Why is Venus the hottest planet?
answer: It has a super thick blanket of carbon dioxide gas that traps heat like a giant greenhouse.

question: What is the greenhouse effect on Venus?
answer: The thick atmosphere traps the Sun’s heat so it can’t escape, making the planet super toasty.

question: Does Venus have any moons?
answer: No, Venus has zero moons.

question: How long is one day on Venus?
answer: One day on Venus (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 243 Earth days – longer than its year!

question: How long is a year on Venus?
answer: A year on Venus is 225 Earth days – shorter than on Earth.

question: Why does Venus spin backwards?
answer: Venus spins the opposite way from most planets – on Venus the Sun rises in the west!

question: What color is Venus in the sky?
answer: Venus is bright white-yellow and is the brightest thing in the sky after the Sun and Moon.

question: Why is Venus so bright from Earth?
answer: It’s covered in thick white clouds that reflect sunlight really well, and it comes quite close to Earth.

question: Can we see Venus without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s often called the Evening Star or Morning Star because it shines so brightly.

question: What are the clouds on Venus made of?
answer: They’re made of sulfuric acid – like nasty, poisonous rain that never reaches the ground.

question: Does it rain on Venus?
answer: Yes, but the rain is sulfuric acid and it evaporates before hitting the ground.

question: What is the surface of Venus like?
answer: It’s rocky with thousands of volcanoes, huge lava plains, and mountains.

question: Are there active volcanoes on Venus?
answer: Scientists think some might still be active – Venus is a very volcanic world!

question: How thick is Venus’s atmosphere?
answer: It’s about 90 times thicker than Earth’s – it would crush you like the bottom of the ocean.

question: Can humans breathe on Venus?
answer: No way! The air is mostly carbon dioxide and full of poisonous gases.

question: Who was Venus named after?
answer: Venus was named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty because it looks so pretty in the sky.

question: How many spacecraft have landed on Venus?
answer: Only Soviet spacecraft have landed – the Venera probes – and they melted quickly!

question: How long did the longest Venus lander survive?
answer: The record is about 2 hours before the heat and pressure destroyed it.

question: Is there lightning on Venus?
answer: Yes! Scientists have seen huge lightning storms in the thick clouds.

question: Why does Venus have almost no water?
answer: The extreme heat long ago boiled all the water away into space.

question: Does Venus have craters?
answer: Not many – lava from volcanoes covered most old craters.

question: What is the highest mountain on Venus?
answer: Maxwell Montes – it’s taller than Mount Everest!

question: How strong is the wind on Venus?
answer: Near the ground it’s slow, but high in the clouds it blows over 350 km/h – faster than a hurricane!

question: What is super-rotation on Venus?
answer: The clouds go all the way around the planet in just 4 Earth days even though the planet spins slowly.

question: Is there ice on Venus?
answer: No – it’s far too hot everywhere for ice.

question: What is Venus’s sky color if you stood there?
answer: It would look orange-yellow because of the thick clouds.

question: Can people ever live on Venus?
answer: Not on the ground, but some scientists dream about floating cities high in the cooler clouds.

question: How much would you weigh on Venus?
answer: Almost the same as on Earth because it’s nearly the same size and gravity.

question: What is a transit of Venus?
answer: When Venus passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a small black dot on the Sun.

question: How often does a transit of Venus happen?
answer: Very rarely – they come in pairs 8 years apart, then wait over 100 years.

question: Does Venus have seasons?
answer: No, because it has almost no tilt – every day is the same.

question: Where is the pressure highest on Venus?
answer: On the surface – it’s like being 900 meters under the ocean on Earth.

question: Why can’t we see the surface of Venus with normal telescopes?
answer: The thick clouds hide everything – we need radar to see through them.

question: What spacecraft mapped Venus with radar?
answer: The Magellan spacecraft in the 1990s made the best maps of the hidden surface.

question: Is Venus getting hotter or cooler?
answer: It’s stayed about the same super-hot temperature for billions of years.

question: What is the Soviet Venera program?
answer: A series of brave Russian probes that took the only photos ever from Venus’s surface.

question: Can you see stars from Venus during the day?
answer: No – the thick clouds make the sky bright all the time.

question: Why does Venus shine so long in the evening?
answer: It follows the Sun down or comes up before the Sun, so we can see it for hours.

question: Does Venus have earthquakes?
answer: They’re called venusquakes – the ground sometimes shakes from shrinking or volcanoes.

question: How many volcanoes are on Venus?
answer: Over 1,600 big ones have been counted, and probably millions of small ones!

question: Is Venus a rocky planet?
answer: Yes, it’s a rocky terrestrial planet just like Earth, Mercury, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you took off your spacesuit on Venus?
answer: You’d be crushed, burned, and poisoned all at once in seconds!

question: Will we go back to Venus soon?
answer: Yes! NASA and Europe are planning new missions like VERITAS and EnVision for the 2030s.

question: What is special about Venus’s day being longer than its year?
answer: It’s the only planet where a day lasts longer than a year – very strange!

question: Why is Venus sometimes called Earth’s evil twin?
answer: Because it’s almost the same size but turned into a deadly hot hell instead of a nice home.

question: What's Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why's Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What's the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why's Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”

question: What spacecraft have visited Mercury?
answer: Two spacecraft: Mariner 10 in the 1970s and MESSENGER from 2004–2015.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What's the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why's Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What's Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where's the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where's the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What's Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What's the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What's a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What's special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why's it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What did MESSENGER discover?
answer: It found ice in deep craters near the poles that never see sunlight, even though Mercury is super hot!

question: Is there ice on Mercury?
answer: Yes, hidden in shadowy craters at the north and south poles where the Sun never shines.

question: Why doesn’t the ice melt on Mercury?
answer: Those craters are always in shadow and super cold, and there’s no air to carry heat to them.

question: How fast does Mercury travel around the Sun?
answer: It zooms at about 47 kilometers per second (29 miles per second) – the fastest planet!

question: Does Mercury have rings like Saturn?
answer: No, Mercury has no rings at all.

question: What's the biggest crater on Mercury?
answer: It’s the Caloris Basin – so huge you could fit the whole state of Texas inside it!

question: Why's Mercury’s sky black even in daytime?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to scatter sunlight, so the sky stays black and you can see stars during the day.

question: Can people ever live on Mercury?
answer: Probably not – it’s too hot, too cold, no air, and too much radiation from the Sun.

question: How many times could Mercury fit inside Earth?
answer: About 18 Mercurys could fit inside Earth.

question: What's Mercury mostly made of?
answer: It has a huge iron core (almost 75% of the planet) covered by a thin rocky layer.

question: Why does Mercury have such a big iron core?
answer: Scientists think a giant crash long ago knocked away most of the rocky outside, leaving the heavy iron.

question: Is Mercury shrinking?
answer: Yes! It’s slowly cooling inside and shrinking a tiny bit, making wrinkle-like cliffs.

question: What are those wrinkle cliffs called?
answer: They’re called “scarps” or “lobate scarps.”

question: How long would it take to drive around Mercury in a car?
answer: If you drove 100 km/h without stopping, it would take about 60 Earth days to go all the way around.

question: Can you explain why Mercury has no seasons?
answer: Actually, Mercury has almost no tilt, so it doesn’t really have seasons like Earth.

question: Where's the hottest place on Mercury?
answer: Right at the point facing the Sun at noon – it can get hotter than 430°C!

question: Where's the coldest place on Mercury?
answer: In the bottoms of polar craters that never see sunlight.

question: Why does the Sun look bigger from Mercury?
answer: Because Mercury is closer to the Sun, the Sun appears almost three times bigger than from Earth.

question: What's Mercury’s gravity like compared to Earth?
answer: It’s only about 38% of Earth’s gravity – you would weigh much less and could jump really high!

question: How many people have walked on Mercury?
answer: Zero – no human has ever been there; only robots!

question: What's the brightest planet we see from Earth?
answer: Venus is usually brighter, but Mercury can look very bright when conditions are right.

question: Can you see Mercury during the day?
answer: Very rarely and only with a telescope because the Sun is too bright.

question: Why does Mercury always show the same side to the Sun sometimes?
answer: Actually, it spins 3 times for every 2 orbits, so different parts get sunlight.

question: What's a transit of Mercury?
answer: When Mercury passes directly between Earth and the Sun – it looks like a tiny black dot crossing the Sun.

question: How often do we study Mercury today?
answer: Scientists use telescopes on Earth and data from the old MESSENGER mission.

question: Will we send another spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: Yes! A mission called BepiColombo (from Europe and Japan) is on its way and will arrive in 2025–2026.

question: What's special about Mercury’s orbit?
answer: It’s the most oval (elliptical) orbit of any planet except Pluto.

question: Why's it hard to send spacecraft to Mercury?
answer: The Sun’s gravity is so strong that spacecraft have to slow down a lot, which takes many fly-bys.

question: How many Earth days equal one Mercury day at the equator?
answer: Because of the slow spin, one full day-night cycle is 176 Earth days.

question: Is Mercury a rocky planet or a gas planet?
answer: Mercury is a rocky (terrestrial) planet, like Earth, Venus, and Mars.

question: What would happen if you dropped a feather and a hammer on Mercury?
answer: They would hit the ground at the same time (just like on the Moon) because there’s almost no air.

question: What's Mercury?
answer: Mercury is the smallest planet in our Solar System and the closest planet to the Sun.

question: How far is Mercury from the Sun?
answer: Mercury is about 58 million kilometers (36 million miles) from the Sun on average – much closer than Earth!

question: Why's Mercury the closest planet to the Sun?
answer: It formed that way billions of years ago when the Solar System was born – it just happened to be the nearest one.

question: How big is Mercury compared to Earth?
answer: Mercury is much smaller – if Earth were the size of a basketball, Mercury would be like a tennis ball.

question: Does Mercury have any moons?
answer: No, Mercury has zero moons.

question: What's the surface of Mercury like?
answer: It’s rocky, gray, and covered in thousands of craters from asteroid hits, just like our Moon.

question: Why does Mercury have so many craters?
answer: It has almost no air or atmosphere to burn up space rocks, so they crash right into it.

question: How hot does Mercury get during the day?
answer: It can reach over 400°C (800°F) – hotter than an oven!

question: Why's Mercury so hot?
answer: It’s very close to the Sun and the sunlight is super strong there.

question: How cold does Mercury get at night?
answer: It can drop to -170°C (-280°F) – colder than a freezer!

question: Why does Mercury get so cold at night?
answer: It has almost no atmosphere to trap the heat, so all the warmth escapes into space.

question: How long is one day on Mercury?
answer: One day (sunrise to sunrise) on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days – that’s a very long school day!

question: How long is one year on Mercury?
answer: A year on Mercury is only 88 Earth days because it zooms around the Sun so fast.

question: Does Mercury have an atmosphere?
answer: It has a very thin layer of gas called an exosphere – it’s almost like having no air at all.

question: Why can’t people breathe on Mercury?
answer: There’s almost no oxygen and the air is way too thin, hot, and full of radiation.

question: What color is Mercury?
answer: Mercury looks gray and rocky, a bit like the Moon.

question: Who was Mercury named after?
answer: It was named after the speedy messenger of the Roman gods because it moves so fast across the sky.

question: Can we see Mercury from Earth without a telescope?
answer: Yes! It’s sometimes visible just after sunset or before sunrise – it’s called the “evening star” or “morning star.”
